div.p: LONDON, Printed by Thomas Harper for Iohn Waterson, and are to be sold at his shop in Pauls Church-yard, at the signe of the Crown. 1637.

div.head: To the right Honorable James, Marquesse Hamilton, Earle of Cambridge and Arran, Lord of Even, Ennerdale and Arbroth, Master of the Horse to his Majesty, Steward of the Honour of Hampton Court, Gentleman of the Kings Bed-chamber, and Knight of the most noble Order of the Garter, and one of his Majesties Privie Councell in both Kingdomes.
div.p:
MEns actions have not their difference alwayes from the relation of their persons, for hee that presented his King with a dish of water, having nothing else, made the gift acceptable. I would use the application to my selfe,
having been one amongst your meanest followers in your Lordships practicall life of a Souldier: what I haue I bestow upon you, and doe hope though it be clothed in the light dressing of a Play, it will not be denied your Lordships acceptance since it contains the Character which History hath left to Posterity of your own truly valiant Countriman: I most humbly beg pardon for my boldnesse, and that I may continue knowne to your Lordship, at the becomming distance of your Honours truly honourer, and humblest servant.

closer.signed: Your Lordships most humble servant and Souldier, William Bowyer.

div.head: Actus I.
div.stage: Enter Halserigge, Thorne, Selby, and Sir Ieoffrey Wiseacres.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: FEllow colleagues, since it hath pleas'd our King,
Renowned Edward, of his speciall favour
To spheare us in this height of eminence,
And maks vs rulers over Scotland,
Lets shew our selves worthy the dignities
Conferred upon us.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: That's not by lenity,
For howsoere the armed hand of war
Ha's made them ours, they are a Nation
Haughty and full of spleen, and must be manag'd
With straighter reins and rougher bitts.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Ahlas,
I finde them easie, tractable and mild,
Autority may with a slender twine
Hold in the strongest head, then what needs tyranny,
Vse rein or bitt, by this all doubts are cleer'd,
'Tis alwayes better to be lov'd then fear'd?
And by your leave, Sir Thomas,
We have good reason to defend our own.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You are as cleer of danger, and as free from foes.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: As he that holds a hungry wolfe by th' eares,
The principles are true, trust not thy wife
With secrets, nor thy vassall with thy life,
Sound example proves it.

sp.speaker: Ieof.
sp.p: And private policy confirms it, I could urge reason why, shew cause, wherefore, and speake to purpose wherby, but my betters are in place, I know them to be pregnant, and a ready wit's worth all.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: For our owne safeties then, and Englands honour,
Let not us lose what our King hardly wonne.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: To that effect called we this solemne meeting,
To which we have summon'd divers: chiefly Wallace,
Late Sheriffe of Ayre, which office tho the King
Conferred on me, the haughty Scot thinks much
To tender up, observe his insolence.

div.stage: Enter Wallace, and takes his place.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Presumptuous Groom, this is a seat for Eagles,
And not for Haggards.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Selbie 'tis a seat,
I, and my Grandsires Grandsire have enjoyed
And held with worship, and till Edwards hand
Remove me from't, Wallace will still posses't.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Proud Wallace dares not.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Selbie, both dares and doe,
And must, and will, tho subject unto Edward,
I'me Selbies equall both in birth and place:
Tho in mine Office, Edward joyn'd you with me,
He never made you ruler over me.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: You'le finde he did, reade that Commission,
And tell me then, if Selby or your self,
Be Sheriffe of Ayre.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: To what my King commands
I humbly bend, resigning on my knee
Both Staffe and Office.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Which thus Selby breaks
Over thy head, and now proud Sir acknowledge
Selby your Ruler, and with your place resigne
Your Castle and your Lands.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: That's not inserted in your Commission.
What the King has given I surrender,
For my Lands they'r still mine own,
Were purchas'd with the sweat of my deer Ancestors,
And ere I lose a pole, a foot, I or the smallest turfe a silly
Larke may build on, Ile lose life.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: At your own choice, either your lands or life,
Or both.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Or neither, royall Edwards mercy
Sits above Selbies malice.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Surly Groom,
Mercie's for subjects, by what Evidence,
Charter or Service do you hold your Land?

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Selby by none, that title which I had
I have given my sonne, a boy of that proud temper,
As should he heare thy insolent demand,
Would pluck thee from thy seat, and lay thy head
A satisfaction at his fathers feet,
But heavens forbid it, Selby thus it stands,
Thou hast my Office, and my sonne my Lands.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: He must shew how he holds 'em.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: So he can,
And Selby will shew evidence sufficient,
Mine, my deere Fathers, and my Grandsires sword.
He weares good evidence about him Selby,
And will upon the least occasion
Both shew and prove it lawfull.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: If the sword be your best plea, y'ave but a naked title,
And by our autority we here command
You and your sonne at our next generall meeting,
To bring in your Surrender, or undergo
The penalty of traytors. Enter Sir John Graham.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Oh you the patrons of poore injur'd subjects,
Do Graham justice, Selbies riotous sonne
Assisted by a crew of dissolutes!
Has stole my onely daughter, and intends
A violent Rape, or which more cuts my soule
A forced marriage.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Inconsiderate foole,
The boy affects her, and with my consent
Intends a lawfull marriage, 'tis a favour
Her betters sue for.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Oh let u'm hate, my bloud
Shall never enter league nor hold alliance
With him that hates my Country.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Rest your thoughts,
He has her, if he likes her he shall wed her,
And Graham as a dowry shall enjoy
Thy present state, revenues, goods and lands,
Fret out thy soule, he shall.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Shall?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I, Sir shall,
It's the highest favour conquest can afford,
For a slave to joyn alliance with his Lord,
And Wallace see present surrender made
Or look for storms.

sp.speaker: Jeof.
sp.p: So say I too, and 'tis not the least part of policy, neither.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Will have my Lands. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Inforce me give a dower.
Misery decre'd above comparison.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Complain unto the King.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: The King alas.
I have heard a story how the subtle Fox
Having stole a Lambe, the family of sheep
Drew a petition, and with full consent
Prefrr'd it to the Lion, he imploy'd
'Bout earnest and more serious businesse,
Appoints the Beare Commissioner, to take up
This bloudy difference; the Beare impannels
A partiall jury all of Wolves, they choose
The Fox their Fore-man, they consult and finde
The sheepish Nation guilty, and with generall breath,
Cast, judged, condemned, and sentenc'd all to death.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Men should have souls.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: But tyrants being no men,
Have consequently none; complaints in slaves,
Are like to prayers made over dead mens graves,
Nor heard, nor pitied, heaven ha's impos'd a curse,
Which suffrance in time may cure, complaints make worse.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Then as it is lets bear't, win heaven to friend
He that begins knows when and how to end. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter yong Selby, and other gallants guarding Peggie.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Maske her, come Peg hide your Scottish face.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Why shild I hayd my Scottis face, my Scottis face is as gude as yare English feace, 'tis a true Scotties feace.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.p: I know 'tis sweet Peggy, and because 'tis not a picture for every Painter to draw forth, let this curtaine be pind before it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Hange yare flee-flaps, na Scottis woeman is asheamed a that luke, that the master painter abuife guifes her, whare mun I gang and now, fay, fay, fay, what lossell am I that am hurrand thus till and fra with sweards and wapins, whay mun backerd men gang fencing and florishing about me, am I yare may-game?

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: No Peggy, th'art my prisoner, but here's thy jaile.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Are yee my jalor? what kin bin you to the hangman? senu you? whare's hee? wha is that foule loone amang you, that mun be my hangman?

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Here's no man here your hangman, or your jailor.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Wha then be you?

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Your friends that hold you only in bonds of love.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I reckand mickle your luife, fay upon sike luife, the awd fellon theef, luif and the true mans siller as you luifand me, I'de rather be a Scutchmans whore, then an English-mans waife, and be dreave toth' Kirke with helters.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.p: Tell mee what proud Scot loves thee, what Scot dare touch thee now th'art Selbies?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Hang thee, hang thee foule meazel'd lowne,
What Scuttishman darres guiff my luif understood
My case, on Gads deare earth yow sud no farder gange
As butchers kie toth the grund he sud yow bange.

sp.speaker: 2 Gall.
sp.l: All mildnesse is in vain, take some rough course.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Toth' Church, away, Ile marry her there by force.

sp.speaker: 1 Gall.
sp.l: Away with her.

div.stage: Enter Wallace, Comming, and Mentith, Peggy runs to Wallace.

sp.speaker: 2 Gall.
sp.l: Yonders Wallace, and's true.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: The Devill and's dambe bee't, budge not.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O my luife these Sotherne Carles mickle wrang 'gainst mee warcke, and now wad force mee gang untill the Kirke, and marry Selby, Wallace my Io not I.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Vnhand that beauteous prize, proud slave, 'tis mine.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Slave! th'art a villain Selby.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Are ye so brave.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Look to my wench.

sp.speaker: Com. Ment.
sp.l: Kill 'em.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: We are no Stares to die by dozens.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.p: Back, the quarrels mine, and if one single Scot proud'st of your swarme dares answer me, step forth.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Your first man I Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Harke Gentlemen, let not so sleight a showre,
Which yet lies hid and wrapt in one poore cloud,
Be by rough winds (raiz'd up by you) dispers'd
Into a generall storme, to many eyes
Of Scots and English shoots, quick lightning forth
Already, but your absence will allay
Those fires which else must kindle, get then away,
Take shelter in yon taverne.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Look to my Peggie. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.p: Guard my love, hee and I will onely exchange cold words.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Now Sir, your cold words.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: This Scotch Lasle I love.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: I love her too, can any words more cold,
Strike to your heart?

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Is she your wife?

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: She's your whore.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Vmh, neither.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: She gangs with me then.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: But the dew lekens not whither,
If you can win her, weare her, she's wholly mine.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: She is?

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: She is, our Lasse are not English common,
I'me right Scotch bred, till death stick to a woman.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: And to the death thou shalt, no more but this,
Thou shalt beare from me Scot.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Instantly.
Make time Sir, of your weapon, time, and place.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: This Whinyard.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: This.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Our swords do now agree, and of one length and scantling.
Why should not we, if we must Surgeons
Have to morrow or anon
If not as good now, 'tis the English fashion
To swagger it out, and then drink and then fight
And kill in cold bloud having slept sound all night,
And oftentimes all gash'd, the seconds fall,
When home in whole skins come the principall.
So about words, the Lawyer wrangling stands,
And loses in mean time his clients lands.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Do'st teach me fencing too in thy own school?
I'le beat thee or be beaten, one draws short breath.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: I feele no sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Yet th'art neere thy death. Fight.

div.stage: Enter 2 Gallants, Coming, Mentith. Wallace loses his weapon.

sp.speaker: 1 Gal.
sp.l: At it so hotly.

sp.speaker: 2 Gal.
sp.l: Kill him, 'tis faire.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Inglorious conquest, for King Edwards crown,
I'de trample on no enemy were hee down.
There— if th'art well, part.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: I'le die, or in thy heart bloud wash this infamy.

sp.speaker: Y. Sel.
sp.l: Mercy on my soule. Dies.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: He's slain.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Shift for your selves, 'twill prove a stormy day.

div.stage: Enter old Selby, Thorn, Haslerig, Peggy, and the two Gallants.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Search, call for Surgeons, follow the murderer.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Wa is me, ligs my luife on the cawd ground,
Let me come kisse his frosty mouth.

sp.speaker: O. Sel.
sp.l: What Scot ist?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oh, 'tis yong Selby!

sp.speaker: O. Sel.
sp.l: Ha'my sonne, who slue him?

sp.speaker: 1 Gal.
sp.l: That fatall hand of Wallace.

sp.speaker: O. Sel.
sp.l: Follow the villain.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Ize jocund and weel now.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Lay upon her fast hold.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Hang me I reck not.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Away with her to prison. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter King Edward, Elinor, Percy, Beaumont, Grimsby, Prince, Sebastian, Bruce.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not all the bloud and treasure we have spent
Like zealous prodigals in Palestine,
Goes half so neer our heart, as that proud France,
Knowing our merit should bar us of our due.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: France dares not.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Yet he does.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Twas not demanded.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: How, not demanded? thinks the bold Lord Percy,
That Grimsby dares not (lawfully employ'd) demand.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: But not command.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Yes command, Percy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Grimsby, thou canst do well in Garison.
Weare shamoys for a grace, project for bloud,
Make eight dayes to one week, turn executioner,
And hangman like send fifty in one morning,
To feed the Crows, and live upon dead pay.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: He's a man worse then dead that—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Stop thy throat or—

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ile cut it.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Cut throat.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis a trade,
By which few prosper, and yet thou art made.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: A man as good as—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A hangman.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: A foule blot
Lies in your throat.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thy foul-mouth, wash it Scot.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In Percies bloud Il'e wash't.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Grimsby you leane
To hard upon our sufferance, and noble Percy.
Our honor'd second in all inward combats,
Thou hast too many worthy parts of man,
To throw thy self on this unequall hazzard,
Grimsby thou standst so much degreed below him,
Both in descent and eminent qualitie,
The many favours we have grac'd thee with,
Blush to have been conferr'd upon a man
No better temper'd.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: May it please my Soveraigne
Confirme his grant touching—

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The Crown of Scotland,
Save other time, Grimsby th'ast raised
A storm which showers of bloud can hardly lay.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Dread Liege,
If all the youthfull bloud that I have spent,
And wealthy honors that my sword hath wonne
Waving the Christian Standard in the face
Of the proud Pagan, in the holy Land,
Merit the name of hangman, Grimsby casts
Them and himselfe at royall Edwards feet,
And like an out worn souldier, humbly begs,
No pension (but look Percy) nor yet office
But leave to leave the Court, and rich in stars
To lose more bloud, or win more worth in wars.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: We will not lose thee Grimsby, valiant Percy,
If love in us, or loyaltie in you,
Have any power.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My Soveraignes pleasure sits above my private passions.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Then joyn hands,
Our subjects both the native of two Lands.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Friends Grimsby.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Friends in shew,
But in my brest bloudy revenge lies ambush't.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Gracious Liege.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Th'art no Musician, Bruce, thou keep'st false time,
We strike a bloudy lachrymae to France,
And thou keep'st time to a Scotch ligge to armes.

sp.speaker: Elenor.
sp.l: Edward will be more kind to Christians.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let Christians be more honest then to Edward,
In expedition of this holy warre,
When France in person was enjoyn'd to march,
To work his safetie we engag'd our own,
Casheer'd his fainting souldiers, and on promise,
Of so much gold at our return, suppli'd
The French designes our selfe, and is our love,
And losse of bloud, halfe which at least had drop'd
Out of French bosomes, quittant with owe none,
Pillage and play the free-butter for more,
The news.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Dread Soveraigne, Scotland is infected
With a most dangerous surfet, it breaks out
In strong rebellion.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: This is your Kingdome Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I have no hand in't tho.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Shouldst have no head, did we but think it,
Whos's the chief?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: One Wallace, a fellow meanly bred,
But spirited above beleefe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Some needy borderer.
How is our bosome parted, is their power
Of any strength? Bruce, leavy powers for France;
If we but thought thee touch'd in't, warlike Percy,
Beaumont and Sebastian fetch him in
Or with a second and more fatall conquest
Ruine that stubborne Nation.

sp.speaker: Ellin.
sp.l: Gracious Edward,
Tho war ha's made them subjects, heaven defend
Subjects should make 'em vassals.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: We conceit you,
If any officer of ours transgresse
Our will, or go beyond his bounds prefix't
Wee'l have his head, he our high worth depraves,
That our free subjects seek to make his slaves.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: We do not.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: See we finde it not.

sp.speaker: Ell.
sp.l: Let Ellianor win so much favour as to march along
Tho conquer'd, 'las we are neighbours of one clime,
And live like them subject to change and time.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Royall Edward,
Though Wallace and some spleenfull dissolutes
Wrong'd with the yoke of bondage cast it off.
Let not the whole Land suffer.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Nor do we wish it Grimsby, should the fates
But turn the wheele we might with them change states,
Be Scotlands subjects, let but Rebellion kneele,
Wee'l weare soft mercy, and cast off rough steele.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I'le undertake it.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let messengers be sent,
To question the proud Rebell, and if Grimsby
Faile in his plot, Northumberland and Clifford
Shall second him in armes, so slight a fo
Must not detain us from our French designes,
Our Queen ha's all our brest, and tho we might
Iustly perhaps confine your liberty,
Bruce, we inlarge it, giving you command
In our French wars, observe him neerly Lords,
I have read this maxime in state policie.
Be sure to weare thy danger in thy eye,
France lights a Comet, Scotland a blazing Star,
Both seeke for bloud, wee'le quench um both with war.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Prethee good Wallace.

sp.speaker: Y. Wal.
sp.l: Ill betides his soule,
That speaks of goodnesse, thinks or meditates
Of any goodnesse more then how to free
Imprison'd Peg.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: But heare me.

sp.speaker: Wal. Laverek
sp.l: Castle weares but a slender bolt of brick.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Turn'd mad!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: And say the moat be fifty fathomes deep,
Fiftie times fiftie, say it reach through to hell,
Wallace will swim't.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Swim't, yes so wilt thrust an oxe into an Eg-shell,
And rost it by Moon-shine, but why should Wallace?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Why should proud Selby, though his forward son
Were justly slain, imprison Peg?
Poor Lambe she is no murtherer.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: In my conscience she ne're drew weapon
In anger in her life.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Not at sharp I think, but by your leave 'tis thought,
She ha's practis'd in private; put Wallace to foil, and made
Him lie at his hanging ward many a time and oft.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Wher's my sonne?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: With Peggie, father, manacles of griefe,
Hang heavy on my sences.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Shake 'em off.
Shew thy self worthy him that thou call'st father,
Or Peggie dies.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: What thunderclap was that?
Able to waken death or shake the shrowd
From off a dead mans shoulders, Peggie dies,
Should thunder speak it, Wallace would sweare it lies,
Who spake that, fatall Nuntio?

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: His breath.
That gave thee being, Haslerigs return'd.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Whence, from the Devill?

sp.speaker: O. W.
sp.l: From England, and this instant
But thou com'st in, and yeeld thy self, her life
Dissolves to aire.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: The charitable Angels waft her to heaven.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Resolve you then to lose her?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: How shall we save her, singly as I am
I will oppose me 'gainst the town of Lavercke,
Swim the vast moat, and with my trustie sword
Hew down the Castle-gates, dishinge the doores,
File off her irons, and through a wall of steele
Attempt her rescue.

sp.speaker: O. W.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Impossible, what's the news from Englands?

sp.speaker: O. W.
sp.l: Grimsby the fire-brand of his Country
Comes to insnare you, on the heele of him
Treads a huge army led on by the Queen,
Percy and Clifford.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Torture and death itself cannot divide us.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Sir John Graham, you shall be the engine
Our policie must work with, streight give out
That hearing of the English expedition,
Our faction is dissolv'd.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Whats's this to Peggies rescue?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Much, this rumour
Blown through the Land will stay the English forces,
And give us time and means to strengthen ours,
That once in act, repair to Haslerig,
Selby and Thorn, urge Peggies innocence,
And for her freedom and your own make faith,
To yeeld me prisoner, 'twill be no doubt excepted,
Your self once pardon'd, and your daughter free.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: What rests for Wallace?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Prosper'd destinie,
If the great cause we undertake be good,
'Twill thrive, if not, be't washt in Wallace bloud.

div.stage: Enter Haslerig, Thorne, Selby, Sir Ieffrey.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Is it by generall Proclamation voic'd
That but proud Wallace yeild, Peg Graham dies,

sp.speaker: Sir Ief.
sp.l: The Cryers are all hoarse with balling of it.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: T'is time for providence to stirre the King,
(I know not upon what complaints) pretends
This rank Rebellion rather, took his root
From wrongs in us, then treacheries in Wallace.
And sends his forces rather to examine
And question our demeanours, then their treasons.
We must prevent it, how think you, Sir Jeffery?

sp.speaker: Sir Jef.
sp.l: Troth even as you think, policie must prevent it.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Sir John Graham craves conference with the Commissioners.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Admit him.
A man, me thinks, of your experience,
Respect and education should not linke
Your self in such a chain of counterfeits.

sp.speaker: Io. Gra.
sp.l: Nor have I Lords, but for your best advantage,
And Englands good, traitors and dottrels,
Are sold for all alike, he that will take them
Must seem to do as they do, imitate
Their vicious actions, strive to take upon him
Their idle follies, joyn companies, and drive
Them into a net suspectlesse.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: So did not Graham.

sp.speaker: Io. Gra.
sp.l: Speak not before your knowledge, you detain
My onely daughter prisoner, will Selby
And his colleagues free her and pardon me,
If I dissolve the brood of traitors
And give up Wallace in bands?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Let's daughter be produc'd.
And th' execution for awhile deferr'd,
Though in her cause Selby ha's lost a sonne
And with him all content, so deer I tender
The peace of Scotland and my Soveraignes good,
As give the traitour to the hand of Law
And with her life take thine.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Good policie.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Aye trowe, ye mean not Wallas his devoire,
And dowty valour merits mare repute nor
Sike fawe language.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A fowle traitour,
I have converst with Wallace, thrown my selfe
Into his bosome, mingled thoughts with him,
And find him neither worthy of thy love,
Nor my alliance.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Fay, sa, not sea, my bunny Wallace luifes me.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Yes as a Politician does a knave
For his own ends, hearing thy death proclaim'd,
But he come in, I told him on't, he smiled.
I urg'd thy love and constancy, still he smil'd,
And to confirm't he basely ha's cut off
All his associates, and given up himselfe
Wholly to me.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Hawd therefor cherritie, and wad yee give
Him to his faes, that gave
His blood to your protect?

div.stage: Enter Wallace, with a guard bound.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: I will and have,
For thine enlargement and my own I have,
No more, here comes the Rebell.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Traiterous man,
Is this thy love? these thy deep promises?
Art thou their Aspies? See Selby here's the hand
Cleft thy sonnes heart.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: For which base villain I'le see thee hang'd.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Thou knowest not thy own eyes,
May feed the Crows assoon as mine, Toads and Snakes
May dig their lodgings in thy brest,
And Devils make faggots of thy bones first,
But my sentence.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Here, Graham, for thy service,
We enlarge thy beauteous daughter.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: A milde exchange,
Angels approve it.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Next, thee to thy Lands and Offices we restore.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: And what for Wallace?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Race him from your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Rac'd byn his name furth the
Whayte buke of life that speaks it.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeff.
sp.l: Hence.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Dear Wallace, thoe ane shrude
Hawd not our bands, wees meet in yander cloud,
Whare na fell Southern nowther can extrude,
Nor bar na fra celestiall pulchritude,
Aid gange thy gate, till heaven, and as we flay,
Like turtle Dowes weese bill & find gude play. Exit Peg.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Rare resolution, what weak heart would faint,
Having so constant a companion?
Selby my soul's bound on a glorious voyage,
And would be free'd out of this jayle of flesh,
Then hinder not my voyage.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.l: 'Tis not policie, wee'l rather set it forwards.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Raise a Gallowes fifty foot high,
ye shall not go by water, wee'l send you up a neerer way.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: All's one,
Axe, halter, famine, martyrdome, or fire,
All are but severall passages to heaven,
Let my soule go the furthest way about,
Come tir'd with tortures, shooting out my heart,
The deepest wounds, like strong Certificates
Find kindest welcome.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Stay th'execution, and having read this Warrant, know
'Tis the Queens pleasure, you send in this traitour
Vnder my conduct to the English Campe:
Rebellion of this nature must be search'd,
With sharper torture.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: I outdare the worst,
He is no man that is afraid of death,
And Wallace his resolve shall out-live breath.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: 'Tis but short-liv'd else, first see him bound and hud-winckt,
Then leave him to my care.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Bear with this Rebell, my love.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: My service.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.l: And my policie to the good Queen and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Come Wallace, now your pride draws neer the fall.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Why Grimsby, if I fall,
'Tis but to gather stronger force to rise,
For as a ball's thrown down to raise it higher,
So death's rebound shall make my soule aspire
The glorious clouds, so long I die secure.
Death cannot threat more then I dare endure.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: No not a man more then my private followers,
The Queen enjoyns it. Exeunt Wa. and Gri.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Farwell, valiant Grimsby, and farwell danger.

sp.speaker: Ief.
sp.l: Policie and all.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: The traitors fled, and Wallace thus supprest,
My sons blouds paid, and his wrong'd ghost at rest.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: And the whole land at quiet, wher's Sir Iohn Graham?
Wee'l joyn him partner in Commission,
'Twill be a means to make our party strong,
And keep down mutinies, search out old Wallace,
And hang the Carle at his own door, Sir Ieffrey,
Place tables in the streets, bonefires, and bels,
Since without cause they murmur, let u'm know
That with their knees wee'l make their proud harts bow.
Sir Jeffrey, be you Master of the Feast,
You keep the purse, if money fall out short,
Send out for more, you have commission for't.

div.head: Act. II.
div.stage: Enter Grimsbie, two or three followers, Wallace bound and hoodwinkt.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.l: WHat talk'st of Conscience? th'art an apparant rebell.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: How can he be a rebell was nere subject?
What right has Edward to the Crowne of Scotland
(The sword except) more than my selfe, or Grymsbie?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: What greater right then conquest?

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Then what cause,
Iuster thou mine? respected Country man,
Thou hast beene nobly valued, and held ranke
With best deservers, look upon the wounds
And mortall stabs of that distressed breast
That gave thee suck; see thy poore brethren slaves,
Thy sisters ravisht, and all out-rages
That bloudy Conquest can give lycence to,
See this, and then aske Conscience if the man
That with his bloud seeks generall reformation
Deserves the name of Traitour,
Whither do'st leade me?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: To Northumberland
And Beaumont.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Butchers do your worst,
Torture, I spit defiance in thy face,
And death, embrace thee with as kinde a narme
As if thou wert.

div.stage: Enter old Wallace, Peggie, Graham, Frier, Coming, and Mentith.

sp.speaker: O. Wa.
sp.l: Thy Father.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: And thy waife.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: In heaven or in a slumber, who resolves me?
Speake, am I dead, or living? or asleep?
Or all, or both, or neither? tell me fate.
Me thinks I see my Father, warlike Graham,
The Fryer, what Peggie too? I prethee joye
Do not ore-flow my sences, deerest friends
Pegg, Father, Coming, Mentith, Graham, see
I am new moulded, and here stands the creature
That by a warrant granted from the Queene
Form'd me from out a second Chaos breath'd
New life, new motions, new dimensions,
To tell the story were to shame the world,
And make all mankinde blush.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: May luive.

sp.speaker: Gra. Fri.
sp.l: Our prayers.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: And all our friendship like a coat of steele
Stand betwixt him, and danger.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: All joyne hands,
Thus like a mountaine Cedar Wallace stands
Amongst a grove of friends, not to remove
For Edwards thunder, nor the frowne of Jove,
I'le hew the yoke from off my countries necke,
Or never house, this religious Fryer
Is a full witnesse to the sacred bond
Twixt heaven and me, which on my part I'le keep,
Or pay the forfeit with my bloud.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Heaven shield
Many a tall wood oake beene fell'd
Ere Wallace stoope, heed Gentrid sawe
Theke sword shall keep in mickle aw,
Fell Sotherne folk, many a crie,
Fray cradled barns, e're he shall flie,
Nurses sighes, and mothers tears
Shall swell the clouds, till thy awne bloud,
Prove false thilk Crag sall nere lig dead.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Shall Wallace live till his owne bloud prove false,
Why, that can never be till palsey age
Hath thrust his icy fingers through my veins,
And frozen up the passages of bloud.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: The town of Lavercke, peopled only with English pride
And overjoyed with thy surprizall are made drunk with mirch,
Bonefires, bels, banquets, and the devill and all
Invite our swords to their sad funerall.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Close with advantage, put your selves in Armes,
And cease their forfeit lives, this holy Frien
Shall first bestow a matrimoniall band
Of our united love, and then my sword
Like winged lightning shall prepare a way,
To Lavercks doom.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Nea marry, stay a wheane,
Dip not thy winyard in the weambe
Of Lavercks town, for giffe thou gange,
Thouse weark thy lives friend mickle wrang,
Thouse come back seafe, but barne I feare,
Ise never blinck upon thee meare,
Kneel till thy Sier his benuson crave,
Next duty bin till dig her grave,
Kisse, kisse thy Peg, for well a neer,
Thase amerous twins sall nere kisse mare,
Till in deaths armes they kisse, thilke state
Stands writ in heaven and seal'd by fate.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Then fate dissembles with mee, this the second time
She has by vision summon'd me to armes,

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Haslerig one way, Selby, and Sir Ieffrey with Frier, Old Wallace and Peggie.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Whom have you there?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Seeking the cave for shelter,
See whom kind fare hath given us.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Trecherous Wallace,
The doting wizzard, and dissembling woman
Chief cause of this Rebellion, now revenge,
Clothe thee in crimson, and prepare to feast,
Wee'l tune such dismall musick, as shall dint,
Smiles in thy shallow cheeks.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Alas, for wae,
What gars this Iewde? what ill intend ye man?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: To make rebellion fatherlesse,
And murder a madding widdower.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Oh, spare mine age.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Pitie my beauty.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: My religion.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Like pity, as thy barbarous sonne bestow'd
On my boyes life, ile print upon thy bosome.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Like pitie as thy husband pitilesse,
Took on the widdows tears, and Orphans cryes
That kist his, and hung about his knees
At Lavercks massacre, Ile shew on thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Thus fell my sonne,
And thus the father of his murtherer fals.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Thus wither'd the pride of Laverck,
And thus fades the flower that caus'd their ruine.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.l: Thus religious cries Exit Haslerig.
Were stopt with steele, and thus religion dies.

sp.speaker: O. Wal.
sp.l: Wallace, revenge me as thou art my sonne.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Revenge thy wait,

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Revenge Religion.

div.stage: A Crie within, Wallace and Conquest. Enter Haslerigg.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Thunderbolts and fire rampier your throats,
The slaves growne infinite,
And moves in every place at once,
Shift for your selves:
Proud Wallace recking in the bloud of Lavercke,
Like a fierce tiger nurst in humane spoyle,
Pursues the slaughter, the barren hills lye strewed
With mangled limbes, such as the gentle night
Rescue from death, fall in the morning flight,
Then flye or fall for company,
Flie from a rebell, but fate keep true course,
Weele ebbe like flouds, to flow with stronger force.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Pursue the slaughter, whilst I, salvation shield me.
Fryer Gertrid answer me, what barbarous hand
Has cast my friend into this cold dead sweat,
Resolve me gentle Father, fellon death,
Tha'st acted sacrilegious burglary, and told my father.

sp.speaker: O. W.
sp.l: Wallace.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: No excuse.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Ay sea husband.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Intreat not, ye are guilty both.
And parties in the deerest robbery,
Then though my wife and father (mercy fate,)
Play not the tyrant with me, do not try
My sences bore their weake abilitie,
Cease to afflict me, or I shall turne Rebell,
And breathe invectives gainst thy power.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: O my deare Wallas for the luive waife,
For siuve of awe sawles, and thy daying waife,
Lift to my latter accens, and attend
Of all thy joyes the derne and dismawe end.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Torture above indurance,
King of dreames dissolve my vision.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Wallace is awake.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: O if I be, let my soule never sleepe,
In the blest bosome of my Ancestors,
Till I have drawne a sea of purple teares
From forth the bosomes of the murderers,
Deere Peggie, father, Gertrid, which way, where
How, when, what meanes, what cause shall I devise
To finde it out, and venge your tragedies?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: I'le teach ye how,
Selby and Haslerigg byn the fell blood-hounds
Whae have hunted laife untill thicke toyles of death,

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Are they turn'd hangmen?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Religious cryes, beauteous entreats, and reverend well-awayes
Could not winne grace or favour,
Wallas revenge my death,
And for a favour keep my hindmost breath. Dies.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: And house it here.

div.stage: Enter Grimsby, Coming, Mentith, and Graham.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Where's Wallas? never eye
Saw such a ruthlesse massacre.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Yes Grimsby,
Wallace can shewe a massacre will proove
Thine but a may-game.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Terrible and strange!

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Dost start at this? then see a spectacle
Of force to stay the motion of the spheares,
Or strike the Sun dead in the browe of heaven,
Looke, and like men short from the browe of thunder,
Fall seneeles, death wounds not so deepe as wonder.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Whose bloody act was this?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: The bloody acts
Contriv'd and plotted by experienc'd villaines.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Who were the authors?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Iudge, they all spake English,
Death best becomes that Dialect,
The first was bloody Hasleriggs, the second
More villaine-like was Selbyes, but the third
All had a hand in.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: English Embassadours. Exit Mess.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: They are welcome, let not one sullen browe
Be seene in all this fiery firmament.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Welcome, your businesse?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Farre more like a Prince,
Then a base rebell looks the Northerne traytor.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Thus to a rebell from a royall King,
If Wallace will confesse himselfe a traytor,
And for his bloody outrages and thefts,
Crave mercy, and submit himselfe to Edward,
There's hope of life.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Still charitable English.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Tis not he sure,
This looks not like a man shold shake a kingdome.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: This it he shall denie,
Rape, murther, ruine, all the sonnes of warre
Stands striving for the prey, and once let loose,
Shall not be checkt, nor taken up, till rage
Be tyr'd with murther, and thy selfe in chaynes
Hang'd like a villaine.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: This is all perfit English, have ye yet spoke?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: We have.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Then we begin,
And to a tyrant thus sayes a loyall subject,
If Edward will confesse himselfe a tyrant,
And kingly fellon, and make good such theft
As he and his have practis'd, sue his peace
By yeelding up his and himselfe to Wallace,
There's hope of life, this if he shall deny
Rape, murther, ruine, all the brood of warre
Shalbe let flie, and never be lur'd of
Till they be gorg'd, and bated with the heart
Of the proud King himselfe.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now speakes a man
Would thrust Iove from Olympus.

sp.speaker: Glas.
sp.l: Calme your spleene,
For now speaks mercy, if your Countryes wrongs
Grow from abuse in Edwards substitutes,
You shall have equall hearing, and the wrongs
Punish't in the deservers.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: This should not be English,
Or if it be King Edward is no tyrant.

sp.speaker: Glas.
sp.l: What answers Walace?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: First pray pardon me,
If like the working of a troubled sea
My bosome rose in billows, for though the windes
That rais'd the storme be downe, yet the deare ruines
Lye still in view, a father, and a wife,
Age, beauty, and religion, for thee
Thousands shall weep, as many wives
Shed purple teares for thee, as many Church-men
Offer their reeking soules in sacrifice,
Court, City, Church, the Chamber of your King,
The Chaire of State shall be no priviledge.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This was not Edwards act.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Yet such as Edward
Plac'd in commission, oh t'was a churlish storme,
And wretched I like a forlorne surviver
Left to interre their deare remembrances.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: But bid relentlesse Edward
Send in the pyrats Haslerigg and Selbye,
And in their hands letters of Murt subscribed,
To make me Master of my owne revenge,
Or like a Ball wrapt in a cloud of fire,
Ruine shall fall upon his palace top,
Pierce through the roofe, and in his chayre of State
Sollicit Iustice.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Into his Princely eares I'le give your wrongs.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Will Walace here advise?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Then be rul'd by Grymsby. Whispers.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Thanks for thy kindnesse. Lords Embassadors,
Such we esteeme you, may we crave perusall
Of your commission?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Wallace shall command it.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Mountfort and Glascott, what third fellow's that?

sp.speaker: Mou.
sp.l: One of our followers.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Good, his name is not inserted,
One call out a headsman.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ambitious rebell, know I am a Prince,
And nephew to the Queene.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Wer't thou the King,
Having no portion in the Embassie,
I'de ha' thy head, goe on, and strike it of,
A second cut his tongue out, and a third
Thrust out their eyes, and put their followers to the sword.

sp.speaker: Omu.
sp.l: Wallace wilbe more milde. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Wallace wilbe more just
Then see the Law of Armes disgrac'd
Sound Drums and drown their cries.
Revenge beats at heavens gates for tyrannies.
So now our tragick Muse jets on the stage,
You that for seeing basenesse want your sight,
Beare with this present our indeer'd, commends
Back to the Queen, and say so much we tender
Her sacred honour, weed not see it wrong'd
Even in her Nephew, you that for sparing speech
In honours cause are justly mute, conduct
This eyelesse messenger, abuse not our intent
In the delivery, make speedy haste,
Lest we be there before you, share in like wrong,
Lend him your eyes, and borrow you his tongue,
If any question you about your harms,
Say Wallace did it in the right of Armes. Exeunt English.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: This will affright the English.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Honor'd Grimsby,
This and ten thousand, thousand more extremes
Cannot appease my anger, you that love me
See those I lov'd inhum'd, my selfe disguis'd,
Will be their Convoy to the English Campe,
And see their usage.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: 'Twill be an act of danger.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: The fitter him that undertakes it, Wallace
Would hold himself not worthy of his fate
Should he bawke danger, disswade not, I will on
Were certain death against my bosome bent,
There's gain in bloud it's honorably spent. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: And such I feare will thine be, honour'd friends
See those remayns of honorable love
Cradled in earth, that once perform'd take Armes
To venge their deaths, Mentith, I attend
The comming of some speciall friends by oath,
Bound to assist us, hark how their friendly drums
Chide them for loytring.
Honor'd Douglas, welcome,
Welcome Mackbeth, and doughty Wintersdale,
Not, unto men more, driven in needfull want,
Could you have brought supply.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.l: The better welcome,
Gold to rich men, and treasure to the wealthy,
Are known companions, wher's our Generall,
The hopefull Wallace?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Gone in quest of death,
Firme as his fate, cause he sees danger shuns him,
He's gone to seek it in the English tents.

sp.speaker: Mack.
sp.l: So Hercules sought honour out in Hell.
He not deserves, the name of Generall,
Dares not face danger, and out-do the Devill.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: And such a man is Wallace, yet least worth
Bears him beyond his strength, bring up your powers
For present charge, his thoughts are tragicall,
And full of bloud, active, and violent all.

sp.speaker: Doug
sp.l: You that best know 'em, feed 'em, all that's ours,
For Scotlands good call Wallaces and yours.

div.stage: Enter Wallace, like a halting Souldier on wooden stumps, with Mountford dumbe, and Glascot blinde.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
Whare man? till the English Campe senu you,
gad sides you gang as I ha' seene mony a your Contrymen like ranck riders amble up westward, you gang the wrang wey man, you sall luse and ye play at shoolagroate, ha' ye na linckers?

sp.speaker: Glas.
sp.l: Ahlas I want my eyes, but have a tongue,
He sees, but cannot speake.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Blyncke at smaw faults then, make me the thirdman, and here's a bunny noyse of Fidlers to gang fra winehouse to winehouse, a blind harper, a mute Cornet, and an old Scotch bagpipe worne toth' stumps.

sp.speaker: Glas.
sp.l: Are you a Scotch man Sir?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Ye marry am I, boddy and sawle a true Scotchman borne, but a true liegeman, hang him that does not luife your King, and your Countryman, what gude victales is that which thilke bonny man that haz glazen windows to his lindging has tyed up in his wallet there?

sp.speaker: Glas.
sp.l: Tis the head of a young murderd gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: What senn you man! a mans scalpe, I doubt ye be three fawse knaves liggand yare heads together about na gudenes, a traytors head ist not?

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: No, but we ha' met with villaynes worse then traytors.
Walace your countryman, that bloody hangman
Mangled us all three thus.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Walas my Countryman, ay say upon him,
Fawe lymmerlike wad I had his head here too,
I zed beare it by my sawle toth' English Campe
Or neere gang farder.

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: Twold be a glorious fight there.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: And you could see it ye sulled sea so man, Wallace
Cut of my shancks too, cause I ran away from him
To serve your gude Prince, harke man, I weare
Na shooen but wodden clampers.

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: Of charity leade us to th' English Campe,
Ye shall besides thanks be most royally payd.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Gang alang man tis hard by now, a mans head
I deempt the pure man had gangand lang to lawe
And sae was thrust out of dores by head and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Glas.
sp.l: No lawe was ere so cruell as Wallas is.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Ne marry? na law sa cruell, fay man fay, I luick'd upon a man a lawe not lang since that sent an awde man and his wife, and many barnes a begging, he had better a slizand theire weazond pipes, and cut theire heads off, but whay was a sa bludy mynded thinke ye?

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: I cannot judge.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Marry man, to get possession of the pure mans house, but there was a cat ganged beyond the man a lawe.

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: A cat goe beyond a lawyer? how?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: I'le tell you how, the man a lawe being got in, the Cat outreach'd him, and leaped to th' top oth lindging, and standand on the tyles, the man a lawe scoarning any ane to be abuife him, offer to fling and ding and downe the poore puscatt, but she meawed at him, and cryed hawd thou foule lowne hawd, as thou thrusts out this poore man and his barnes, sa there is ane abuife sall thrust out thee, stay blind man, here comes souldiers.

div.stage: Enter Bolt with three or foure tattar'd Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Stand que voula, spyes about our trenches?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: And see they have knock'd some man downe sirra,
You that carry two faces under a hood,
What are you?

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: He must be prest, he will not speake.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: What art thou I charge thee? hast thou neere a tongue
In thy head? give the word.

sp.speaker: Gla,
sp.l: He has no tounge indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: Two heads and neere a tongue, what are you?
That like a blind asse stand still, and cannot tell us so.

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: I'me blind indeed,
Conduct us to the Lords i'th' English Campe.

sp.speaker: 2 So.
sp.l: How Lords, are you Ladyes that you long for Lords?

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.p: Do you take us for gulls to goe tell the Lords here's a dumbe man would speake with'em, what are you sirra? come halt not, lets not find you in two tales y'are best.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Ize a Scotch man sir, ye shall neere find me in twa tales.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A Scotch man sir, do you know where you are sir?
Your blew bonnet on before an English scull,
Where's your leg sir, when an Officer speaks to you?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: My leg sir is not in my galligaskin and flop as yours is, I'ze a pure Scotch souldier out at heeles, and am glad to bestirr my stumps, guide these gude men y'are wranged Countrymen, wha that fawse traytor Wallace has misusand in sike wise.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Wallas, oh slave!

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: I shall live (fellows in armes out at Elbows)
To give fire to my peece with a burnt ynch of match
Made of that rascals fat of mawegut.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: By my sawle sir wad I might come
To'th making of sike a match.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: Here's my hand, because thou sayest so,
Thou shalt be by when I make him give fire to my touch-hole.

div.stage: Enter Queene Elenor, Clifford, Percy, Beaumont, and others.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: The Lords are going to view the trenches.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: Every man to his parrapet,
To your trenches you tatterd roagues!

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Its well done fellowes.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: Cry your Lordship mercy,
This blind buzzard here cannot see,
Whither will you march headlong my friend?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What men are these?

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: I leave them to your Honors sifting,
I have fortifications to look too.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: There's drinking money, hence to your works.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: Blesse your honours. Exeunt Bolt. and Sould.

sp.speaker: Percy.
sp.l: What men are these, I aske, will no man speak?

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: Heare and in hearing wish the sound unheard,
Youthfull Sebastian nephew to the Queene
Longing to see the man fam'd for th' excesse
Or goodnes and of badnes, seeing unjoyned
In honored Embassie disguis'd attempted
The rebell Wallaces presence.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Glascot and Mountford.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Who did this damned villany?

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: Our message told,
The traytor newly set on fire with madnes,
Showing the mangled bodies of a Fryer,
His wife and father, burst out into flames
Hye hot and violent, In which fierce rage
Revolted Grimsby knew Sebastian
(Tho Herald like he went disguis'd) and seazed
Him and us for three intelligencing spies,
Cut off his head, his tongue, and Glascots eyes.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Hang up this, provide for these, trufle him up.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: What sen ye man? Exeunt Moun. and Glas.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What slave, what Turke that murders his owne brethren
Durst play the tyrant thus? hang all the Nation
Whom we have tane to mercy, I'le not spare
Fathers, nor mothers, nor their bawling barnes,
fire their houses, hang up this tike first.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Ah bonny men, I met um playe and at bo-peep, & gangand out a their way, and sall I be hanged for my good deeds of charrity, I'ze a poor Scutch souldier, and am ron away from that Rebell Wallas, to feight and for your gude Prince, ah he's a gude King, and y'are all bonny men, I'ze follow ye all to the death, and to the Devill, and ony man dare gang so far for all my clutches, giffe I clutch Wallace, he's neer carry it till hell nor heaven.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: If he do, may Percies name be crost
Out of the roll of men.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: So much swears Clifford.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sneak not away sirra, y'are not gone yet.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: I ken it vary weel.
I'ze not gangan to hanging yet.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Yet though a traitour, thus much let me speak
For absent Wallace, were the case your own,
Or one that's baser having any spirit,
A murder'd father and a bleeding wife,
Mangled before him, would strike fire in snow,
Make loyalty turn traitor, and obedience
Forget all duty.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: But our Nephews death
And the disgrace done our Embassadours.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: They then put off their title, and put on
The name of spies, when in their companies,
They take disguis'd observers.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: By my sawle the English are gallant men.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No snare to intrap this Wolfe?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: How Northumberland, intrap a fo?
Sure 'tis no English word,
Clifford at least was ne're acquainted with't.
Give him fair summons, dare him to the field,
And trap him then.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Ah bony man!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: His being a traitour warrants it, dispatch
A second message with acknowledgment
Of former wrongs to our Embassadours,
With promise of a friendly enterview
Early to morrow, impartially to heare
Their wrongs, and mildely minister redresse.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Insnare him so and spare not, for you'le finde I feare,
That Selby, Haslerig, and the rest
Lay yokes too heavy on the Nations neck.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: If they do punish 'em.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Punish 'em, sdeath hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Shall we agree to have such message sent
To allure this bloudy Tygre into th' net
And waking then or sleeping kill him.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: All stratagems are lawfull 'gainst a fo.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Do what you will, but my consent is no.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I'le venture to the Rebell.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Do good Beaumont, Scotchman dar'st thou conduct him as his guide?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: But return sirra, or the next time we take yee
Y'are Crag shall pay for't.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I'ze not run away fra yee, giffe I do hang mee and drae mee, cum bully Joe, I dare not gang to the Scottis Campe, th'yle sa slay upon me, Ise near cum back agen, but Ize bring you where yee shall see that Lowne Wallace.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That's all I wish; lead on.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Marry sall I, luke to your selfe,
Ise thrust you into the Dewles chops.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: For getting out let me scuffle.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Consult for present execution.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: What is, what should, what can this Wallace be?
Whom fame limbs out for such a gallant peece,
And is so curious in her workmanship,
No part deforms him,
Yet Wallace is a Rebell, his chief scandall
Is poverty of Gentry, by my sword
Wert no impeach to my deare Ancestors,
I well could spare him some of my unus'd titles,
Or would at martiall gaming so I might lose
And Wallace winne so much of Cliffords honour,
Our stocks might be alike, but I exceed,
This night he is betray'd, he shall not,
I'le turn traitor first he shall not,
Call Beaumont back, or else by Cliffords honor,
An oath which I esteem above my life,
I will turn traitor, and reveale your plots,
Call him back.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is Clifford mad?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: No Percie's lunatick, suppose he be a traitor
And discipline of the field allow the act,
What honour is it for a herd of yours
To worry a sleeping Beare? goe call him back.

div.stage: Enter Beaumont with a wooden stump.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: See he comes uncall'd.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: The news.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: News call you it, let no Scot come neer your tents,
Wallace sends you this token.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Ha, how, Wallace.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Was that the traitor?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: By Mars his helme, a compleat Warrior,
I so love his worth, I'le court it with my sword.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Had you but stood in distance of his thunder,
For, we parted just where our trenches ended,
You'de ha' sworn the God of War had spoke,
Quoth he, tell Percy, he shall not need.
To hunt me in my tent, I'le rouze him in's own,
And bids me give you this wooden stumpe,
And sweares to make you weare it,
If you dare stand him in the field.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Base Rebell, why durst he not stand here?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: None pray'd him stay,
Twas manners being not welcom'd to get away.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: He sends, commends to Clifford, with this wish,
That if at this great match of life, and death,
He chance to lose the smallest part of honour
His sword may joyn't, he knows best how to use it.
At my return from France, quoth he, this vow
Which I have promis'd shall be surely payed,
Our Country overtopt with tyranny,
Makes us flie thither for succour, Aeolus,
Let favourable winds and tydes assist me,
That spoak, revolted Grimsby and his powers
Met him in Armes, what further he intends,
Harke their Drum tels, here my Commission ends.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Lets send him commendations too, beat ours.

div.head: Act. III.
div.stage: Enter Sir Ieffrey and Bolt with a Trunke.

sp.speaker: Ief.
sp.l: Set downe Bolt, I can beare with thee no longer.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: No more can I beare any longer with you, Sir Ieffry, but what a reeling drunken sot is this sea, that casts up such gobbets as this, is this a windfall or no now sir Ieffery? your Worship knows both the tags and points of the law.

sp.speaker: Ief.
sp.p: Yes sure it is a windfall, for as we walk'd upon the shore, we saw the ship split, this fell out, the winds were the cause, therefore it must needs be a windfall.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.p: Well some body ha's had but a bad fish-dinner to day.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: The Seas have crost them that sought to crosse the Seas, and therefore for my part I'le never meddle with these water-works.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Nor I, lets be more wise then a number of gallants, and keep the land that's left us, did you ever see such gambols as the waves made sir Ieffery?

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.p: Never since I wore the nightcap of Iustice, and that this her dudgeon dagger was a my side.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.p: Did you note what puffing the winds made till they got great bellies, and then how sorely the ship fell in labour.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Didst heare what a dolefull cry they made,
When their maine yard was split?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Alas sir, would it not make any man roare that had but an inch of feeling or compassion in his belly to have his mayne yard split, and how the marriners hung by the ropes like Saint Thomas Onyons.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: I saw it Bolt with salt eyes.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: So that you may see at sea however the winde blowes, if a man be well hung, hees cocke sure.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: But Bolt what dost thou thinke this to be?

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: A matter of some weight as I take it.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.p: I hope 'tis gold 'tis so heavy, and 'twas going out of the Land.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.p: Like enough, for gold goes now very heavily from us, and silver too, both red chincks, and white chincks flie away, but sir Ieffery, if this be gold, how rich is the sea, thinke ye, that has innumerable such sands?

sp.speaker: Ief.
sp.l: More rich then the land, and more fat.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
So it had need, for the land looks with a leane
payre of cheeks, yet it has an excellent stomach, it digests any thing.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.p: Then tis like the sea, for all's fish that comes to net there.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.p: I'le tell you the mystery of that, looke what mouthes gape at land, the selfe same gape at sea, all the land is one kingdome, and all the sea another.

sp.speaker: Ief.
sp.l: And people in't.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: And people in't (right worshipful) but they all go Westhod, as there are good and bad here, so there are good and bad there, gulls here, gulls there, as great men here eate up the little men: so Whales feed upon the lesser fishes.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Belike then the watry common wealth are ill govern'd.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: No bravely, for heroicall Hector Herring is King of fishes.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Rich cobs his good subjects, who at Yarmouth lay downe their lives in his quarrell, sword-fish and Pike are his guard.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: On.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Fresh Cods the gallants, and sweet slipper the Knights, whiting-mopps the Ladies, and Lillie-white-mussels the wayting-gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Dangerous meat to take too much of.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: But who the pages?

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Shrimps.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: No, no sir, perriwinckles are the pages, perriwinckles.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: No Iustices among them?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Yes sir Ieffery, Thornebacks are the Iustices, Crabs the Constables, whom if you butter with good words, 'tis passing meat at midnight.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Dogfish are Iaylors,
And Stockfish the poore common people.

sp.speaker: Je.
sp.l: Indeed they live hardly.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: But sir they are beaten too't, then have you wet Eeles for whores, and great Oysters for Bawds.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Why great Oysters Bawd?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Because for the most part they are stewed.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Lastly, because no Kingdome can stand without laws, and where law ha's her eyne, there Lawyers & Pettifoggers swarme, therfore the Lawyers here are sharks, and gudgeons the poore Clyents.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Wa ho ro sol fa, sol fa.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Harke.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Peace Bolt.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: Nay peace you good sir Ieffery, peace, peace.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Sol la, sol la sol la sol la.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Some Faulconers teaching his Hawke pricksong, Shall I mocke him in's owne key.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Sol fa sol fa, here boy.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Here boy, wa ha ho ho,
All haile to you two.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And all snow to you sir.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Sirra what art thou that wishest all the haile to light upon us two?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Answer wisely to my master,
For hee's a Iustice of peace, and you'l be smelt out.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: I am a drown'd rat.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: A Rat?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Do you take sir Ieffrey for a Rat-catcher,
Youle tell a sweet tale for your selfe anon.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Pox rot you, I am shipwrack't,
Give me some meate.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Shall I make his Mittimus? he begs sir.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: iha met more then my match, Neptune and I,
Wrastling for fals, he got the masterie,
I'me with his beating bruis'd, weary, cold, weak,
Liquor'd soundly.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: He's drunk.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Yet so thirstie scarce can speak,
If ye be men, help me to food and fire.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: What Countryman art thou sirra?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: A Scot, give me some victuals pray.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: No minde but of thy belly.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Sirra, sirra, you are a Scot, and I a true English Justice.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Not a word of Latine, neither Justice, nor Clarke.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Peace Bolt in the Kings name, I charge thee, if you will eat bread earn bread, take up this luggage, sirra, follow me home to my house, thou shalt have good bread, good drink, and good fire, up I command thee.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: I am necessities slave, and now must beare.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Must! nay, shall: are not the English your good Lords and Masters?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Well they are.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Do you grumble sir, on sir Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Have an eye to him Bolt, lest he give us the slip,
And were you in this terrible storm at Sea say you?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Over head and eares, sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: If th'execution had been upon the land Sir Ieffrey, as 'twas upon the Sea, your worship had been in a worse pickle then he.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Why Knave? why?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Because he that ha's a bad name is half-hang'd,
And your worship knowes, ye have but an ill name.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Thou Varlet is not wise good?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Yes, come along porter, wise is good.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: And is not acre good?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Yes passing good.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Why should Wiseacre being put together be nought then?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Is not Plumb-porridge good, Sir Ieffrey?

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Would I had this trunk full of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Peace Greedi-gut, Plum-porridge is good, and Bag-pudding is good, but put them together, and they are filthy meat.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Well, that's true.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Right sir. Sets down the Trunk.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Hunger is good, and two Woodcocks are good, But the feathers of those two Woodcocks must be pluck'd first.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Hold I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Yare a scurvy Iustice, yare man's an Asse, and you another with a velvet foot-cloth on your back, I ken ye vary weel, and Ise knock ye vary weele, if any thing be worth victales, it goes down here.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: The Devill choake you, if you be a man of your word.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Wiseacres, if you would fain know who ha's got this trash from yee, 'tis I, Wallace the Scot.

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.l: Wallace.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Flie sir Ieffrey,
He calls us Woodcocks, let's flie and raise the Country.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: D'e ye grumble? raise the Devill and spare not.
Wert thou a chest of gold, I'de give thee all for victuals,
Hunger, they say, will break stone wals,
Your chops are not so hard,
Ye shall burst tho with iron ribs ye were bar'd,
sp.p: — victuals— wine too,— few justices doe feed the hungry thus, o these Wiseacres are the bravest fellowes, specially English Wiseacres.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I'le now be my own carver, misery and age
Want and despaire have brought me to deaths doore,
And shall I not enter? yes I will, this key
Shall doo't, is death so surly, may a poore man
Speake sooner with a King then speake with him
When he has most need of him, ugly leane slave,
So I may see him, no matter for a grave.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: How now, what do'st looke for?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: For that which a quarter of the world
Wants, a tree to be hang'd upon.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Art weary of thy life?

sp.speaker: Selby.
sp.p: Yes all men are of their old wives, my life ha's gone up and downe with me this threescore and odde yeares, 'tis time to be weary on't I thinke now.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: And when tha'st hang'd thy selfe, whither do'st thinke to go then?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: To the Linnen-draper.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: What Linnen-draper?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: The richest in the world, my old Grandmother the Earth, how many paire of sheets has she had, thinke ye, since Adam and Eve lay together, It's the best Inne to lye at, a man shall be sure of good linnen.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Who dwels hereabouts?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: One upon whom all the poore in the Countrey cryes out.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Whos's that?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p:
Scarcity, dearth, penurie, famine, hunger, I have
not knowne that man lives by food these foure dayes, and therefore I'le descend to th' Antipodes, because I'le kicke at this world.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Stay, famine shall not kill thee, sit and eate
Thy belly full, thy cares in good wine drowne,
By my owne fall I pitty others downe,
Is't not good cheere?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Brave, I thanke you for it, how many beggers does a rich man eate at his table at one meale, when those few crummes are able to save a mans life, how came you sir into this fearefull nest of Screech-owles and Ravens?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Cast up by the Sea, I was shipwrack'd and lost all my company.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Would I had beene one of 'em, I have lost more then you have done, I ha' lost all that I had but my sinnes, and they hang so heavy on my eye-lids, I can scarce look so high as the brimmes of my hatt to heaven, I have such a minde downwards, I have almost forgot who dwels over my head.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Looke up, be not afraid, there raignes no tyrant,
Wud thou hadst beene with me at sea.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: So wud I.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Hadst thou an Atheist been, and God not known,
thou'dst found him in the deepe, there hee's best showne,
He that at Sea is shipwrackt, and denyes
A Deity (being there sav'd) damn'd lives and dyes,
Man no where in the twinckling of an eye
Is throwne so neare to hell, or rais'd so high
Towards heaven, then when hee's toss'd upon the waves
It must be a hand omnipotent there that saves,
But how came you sir hither?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I was banish'd from England (but that grieves me not)
But I kill'd an old man, he was call'd Wallace.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Wallace, and me thinks hee's still at mine elbow.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Elbowe? idle: Selby my fathers murderer?
Thinke not upon it, sit eat heartily
Thy last, sit downe, I say, never to rise,
Drinke wine, drinke deepe, let thy soule reele to hell.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I am almost dead with cold.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: I'le fetch dry sticks,
And with two flints kindle fire, beat out his braines:
O that physicke had the power to make thee yong,
I'de fetch thee drugs from th'utmost of the world,
And then would arme thee, or, into thy veines
Halfe my owne bloud I'de power, to lend thee strength,
That I might kill thee nobly.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Be quiet, I'le pay thee.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: A slumber took me, and me thought old Wallace
Clapt me upon the shoulder with one hand,
And with the other pointed to his wounds,
At which I started, spake, but know not what,
I'me cold at heart.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: I'le seeke for fire.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I thanke ye, if what I utter ye tell to any, I am a dead man,
You have me at your mercy, and may betray me.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Not I, eate and get strength, I'le seek for fire,
Vnlesse I be a devill (tho I have cause
To kill thee) yet my quicke hand shall eschew it,
Thy carelesse confidence does bind me to it,
This mercy which I show now is for Gods sake,
In part of payment of his showne to me,
If I should kill thee now, thou owest me nothing,
Live, and be still my debter, I shall do thee
More harme to give thee life, then take it from thee,
Heaven in my fathers bloud who is chiefe sharer,
Shall strike for me a revenge more just and fairer.

div.stage: Enter Haslerig, poore as th'other with Apples.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Selby, Selby,
How like a Churle thou feed'st alone,
And greedy art to fatten misery— Selby?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Look I ha' found a jenniting tree.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Where stands it?

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: I'le not tell thee; see brave food.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Lets taste it.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Not a paring, what hast there?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: The dole of plenty.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Good old Rogue I thank thee,
I have a stomack like a Lawyer,
Lets eat fruit when we have fill'd our bellies.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Not a bitt.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Not a paring of cheese.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: I must.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Thou shalt not, I pay thee in thy own coyne.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Thy doting age is almost at her journies end,
My youth having far to go needs more provision,
And ile have this—

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Hands off Kils him.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: You Dog, you old Devill.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I thank thee, thou hast cut the threed in two,
Of all my woes, heaven pardon us both, adue.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Selby, no water from the hallowed Fount,
Toucht thee, thou art so fatall, Selby, dead!
Gods building which ha's stood this threescore yeeres,
This ha's defac'd, would it were up agen
With ruine of mine own, I never knew
Partners but one still th'other overthrew,
Thou and I did set up with one stock of care
I have undone thee, and now all's my share,
'Tis not so sinfull nor so base a stroke
To spoile a Willow as an old reverend Oke,
From me th'art gone, but i'le from hence nere fly,
But sit by thee, and sigh, and weep, and die.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Stand, that's he who turns his taile to us, which is as much as to say, A fart for your Worship.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Down with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Jef.
sp.p: Peace, it's a wilde Bull wee come to set upon, and therfore let those Dogs that can fasten bite soundly.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: My harts, we come not to bait an Asse in a Beares skin, but a Lion in his own skin, he's a traitour.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: How know we that?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Thus, he hides his face, and wee are not to back a traitor, Sir Jeffrey, you'le get between mee and the Gallows, if I strike him down.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I'le enter into a Recognizance to hang before thou shalt hang.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: If you see my heart begin to faint, knock you mee down to put life into me.

sp.speaker: Ief.
sp.l: Feare nothing. Bolt strikes him down.

sp.speaker: Has.
sp.l: Be damn'd both gods and men the act detest,
Oh heaven; wipe this sinne out for all the rest.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Your sins are wip'd out sir, your Scottish score is paid sir.

sp.speaker: Ief.
sp.l: Is he down?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: He sprawles, stay there's one asleep by him,
Shall I kill the lice in his head too?

sp.speaker: Ief.
sp.p:
No, wake not a sleeping Mastive, the Kings in the field, Lets post to him, Bolt, thou shalt be a Knight as deep as my selfe, for this manly deed, as ye go through the
Country, cry aloud, the traitor's dead.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Cry it out at the Crosse, and at the old Palace,
That Bolt was the man that brain'd lusty Wallace.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: The traitor's dead, the traitor's dead, &c.

div.stage: Enter Wallace, with dry sticks and straw, beating two flints.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Thou shalt have fire anon old man, ba', murdred?
What shouldst thou be? the face of Haslerig,
'Tis he, just heavens ye have bestow'd my office
Vpon some other, I thank ye that my bloud
Stains not my hand, however both did die
(In love or hate) both shall together lie,
The Coffin you must sleep in is this Cave,
Whole heaven your winding sheet, all earth your grave,
The early Lark shall sadly ring your Knell,
Your Dirge be sung by mournfull Philomell,
Instead of flowres and strewing herbs take these,
And what my charity now fails to do,
Poor Robin-redbrest shall, my last adue,
I have other streames to swim through, or calme
Venture, 'tis brave when danger's crown'd with palme.

div.stage: Enter with Drum and Colours, the Generall of Scotland, with Grimsby, Mentith, Coming, and Souldiers with blew Caps.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Vpon this field-bed will we lodge this night,
The earth's a souldiers pillow, here pitch our tents.

sp.speaker: Men. Om.
sp.l: Vp with our tents.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: To councell, beat a Drum.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Beat it for action then, and not for words,
Vpon our Speare points our best counsell fits,
Follow that (noble Generall) up with no tents
If you dare hold me worthy to advise,
But with an easie march move gently on.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: You speak against the Scholership of war.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Now their Beef-pots, and their Cans,
Are toss'd in stead of Pikes, their Armes are thrown
About their Wenches middles, there's their close feight,
Let us not lose the forelock in our hands,
Of us they dream not, yet we are as free-born
As th' English King himself, be not their slaves,
Free Scotland, or in England dig our graves.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: A Wallace, A Wallace, A Wallace!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Rugerosse, what cry is this?

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: Of the whole Army,
Grown wild twixt joy and admiration,
At the sight of Wallace.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: That dreadlesse Souldier,
For whom all Scotland shed a sea of teares
As deep as that in which men thought him dead,
Sets with his presence all their hearts on fire,
That have but sight of him.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: A Wallace, A Wallace.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Intreat him hither.

div.head: Act. IIII.
div.stage: Enter Wallace with Drum, Colours and Souldiers, they all imbrace him.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: D'ee heare th' English march? they are at hand.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Now Grimsby, they for Pikes are tossing Cans.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I am glad our thunder wakes 'em.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Shall we on?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Whether ist best to stop 'em in their march,
Or here to make a stand and front 'em.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Stand.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Or else retire back to the spacious Plaine
For battaile far more advantagious.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: And so retiring be held runawayes.
Here stands my body, and ere this English Wolves
Stretch their jaws ne're so wide, from hence shall drive
I'le rather lie here fifty fathome deep,
Now at this minute, then by giving back
One foot, prolong my life a thousand yeers.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Then let us die or live here.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Arme, arme.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Fall back? not I, death of my selfe is part,
I'le never flie my self, heres no false heart:
Lets in our rising be, or in our falls
Like bels which ring alike at Funerals,
As at Coronations, each man meet his wound,
With self-same joy as Kings go to be crown'd,
Where charge you?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: In the battaile, valiant Grimsby
Is Generall of our Horse, the infantry
By comming is commanded, Mentith and you
Shall come up in the Reare.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: The Reare.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: No, sir.
Let Mentith, Wallace shall not.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: He may choose.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Were I to hunt within a Wildernesse
A herd of Tigres, I would scorn to cheat
My glories from the sweat of others brows,
By encountring the fierce beasts at second hand,
When others strength had tam'd him, let me meet
The Lion being new rowz'd, and when his eyes
Sparkle with flames of indignation,
I ha' not in the Academe of War
So oft read Lectures, chief now to come lag,
Ile ha' the leading of the Van or none.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Then none, you wrong us all,
Men now are plac'd, and must not be dishonour'd.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: So, dishonour'd.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Charge in the Reare for Gods sake, now to stand
On terms of worth hazards the fate of all.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Well be't so then, the Reare, see you yon hill,
Yonder i'le stand, and tho I should see Butchers,
Cut all your throats like sheep, I will not stirre
Till I see time my selfe.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Your pleasure, on,
Each Leader spend his best direction. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter King, Percy, and Bruce, Hertford, Sir Ieffrey, and Bolt, with Drums and Colours.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Which is the fellow?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am the party sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Stand forth before the King,
