sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.l: Nay, he's no sheep-biter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Didst thou kill Wallace?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Yes marry did I sir, if I should be hang'd here before yee, I would not deny it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How didst thou kill him? hand to hand?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Hand to hand, as Dog-killers kill dogs, so I beat out his brains I'me sure.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Me thinks, thou shouldst not look him in the face.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: No more I did, I came behind his back & felld him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Art thou a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: I am no gentleman borne, my Father was a poore Fletcher in Grubstreet, but I am a gentleman by my place.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What place?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A Justices Clarke, sir Jeffery Wiseacres.

sp.speaker: Je.
sp.p: My man, if it please your Majesty, an honest true Knave.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Give to sir Wiseacres Clark an hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.l: I thank your grace.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: God confound all your foes at the same rate.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But if this Wallace, sirra, be alive now,
You and your hundred pounds shall both be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: Nay I will be hang'd ere I part from my money,
Who payes, who payes?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Charge, charge.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The news brave Clifford.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.p: The daring Scot fuller of insolence then strength Stand forth to bid us battell.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Throw defiance back downe their throats, and of our Heralds
Northumberland the honor shall be thine, tell'um
We come to scourge their pride with whips of steele,
Their City hath from Iustice snatch'd her sword
To strike their Soveraigne, who ha's turn'd the point
Vpon their own breasts, tell 'em this.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I shall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Where's noble Bruce?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: I have a message, but tis more honorable, sent to you too,
The Herald saies that Wallace dares ye, his
Spite is all at you, and if your spirit be great
As his, you finde him in the reare.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hang up that wiseacres, and the fool his man.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: My master, not me sir, I have a Recognizance of him
To stand betwixt me and the gallows.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A Kings word must be kept, hang 'em both.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: One word more good Sir, before I go to this geere,
If a Kings word must be kept, why was it not kept, when he gave me the 100. li. wipe out one, I'le wipe out the other.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: That jest hath sav'd your lives, let me see you fight to day.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Bravely like Cocks.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: Now Wallace look to your coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Move on.

div.stage: Enter to them the Scottish Army, and are beaten off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We have flesh'd them soundly.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: I would not wish to meet with braver spirits.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Stay, Bruce, what's yonder on the hill?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: They are Collors.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why do they mangle thus their Armies limbes?
Whats that so farre off?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Sure 'tis the Reare, where burns the black brand,
Kindles all this fire, I meane the Traytor Wallace?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What turn'd Coward?
A dogge of so good mouth, and stand at bay?
If in this heat of fight we breake their ranks,
Presse through, and charge that devill, Bruce thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: To hell if I can chase him.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Charge up strong, harke, brave,
Let now our hands be warriors, not our tongues.

div.stage: Enter the Scottish Army, Generall Grimsby, Coming, Mentith.

sp.speaker: A cry within.
sp.l: They flye, they flie.

sp.speaker: Generall.
sp.l: The English shrink, knit all our nerves
And fasten Fortunes offer.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Keep steedy footing, the daye is lost if you stir,
Stirre not, but stand the tempest.

sp.speaker: Coming.
sp.l: I cry on.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: So do not I, this starting backe is but an English earth-quake, which to dust, shakes rotten towers, but builds the sound more strong.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Lets on, and dare death in the thickest throng.

div.stage: Enter the English Army, and encompasse them.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Did I not give you warning of this whirpoole
For going too farre?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: We are all dead men, yet fight
So long as legges and Armes last.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: In how quicke time
Have we about you built a wall of brasse?
Had he whom here you call your Generall
A Souldier beene remarkable of great breeding,
And now to be caught with lyme-twigs?

sp.speaker: Generall.
sp.l: Keepe our ground.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: If we must fall, fall bravely.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Wound for wound.

sp.speaker: Alarum.
sp.l: Exeunt King and Bruce pursuing the Scots.

div.stage: Clifford, Percy, Grimsby, and Generall stay.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.p:
Take breath, I would not have the world rob'd
of two such spirits, poast to the King, and tell him that the noblest Harts of the whole heard are hunted to the toyle,
Aske whether they shall fall, or live for gaine.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.l: I shall.
Charge.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: For honours sake come downe, and save thy Countrey.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Whose is the day?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Tis Edwards, come rescue
Our Generall, and the noble Grimsby.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Our Generall and stout Grimsby are enclosd
With quick-sets made of steele, come fetch them off,
Or all is lost.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Is the day lost?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Lost, lost.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Vnlesse the day be quite lost, I'le not stirre.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Tis quite lost.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Why then descend amaine, art sure tis lost?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Then wee'le winne it againe.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: The King proclaimes that man a traytor
That saves when he may kill.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Charge them blacke day,
The Lyon hunts a Lyon for his prey.
A fight.

div.stage: Enter Wallace and Souldiers, beat off the English, the Generall, and Grimsby slaine.

sp.speaker: Generall.
sp.l: Too late.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Why then farewell,
I'le make what haste I can to follow thee,
Bruce, Bruce, I am here, 'tis Wallace calls thee,
Dares thee.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Tho I nere stoopt unto a traitors lure,
I scorne thine, why do'st thou single me,
Yet turnst thy weapon downward to the earth?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Lets breathe and talke.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I'le parly with no traytor but with blows.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Ye shall have blows your guts full,
I am no traytor.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Why 'gainst thy Soveraigne lifts thou then thy sword?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: You see I lift it not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Tell Edward so thy King.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Longshancks was never Soveraigne of mine,
Nor shall whilst Bruce lives, Bruce is my Soveraigne,
Thou art but bastard English, Scotch true borne,
Th'art made a mastive 'mongst a heard of wolves,
To weary those thou shouldst be shepheard of.
The fury of the battell now declines,
And take my counsell, though I seeme thy foe,
Wash both thy hands in bloud, and when anon
The English in their Tents their deeds do boast,
Lift thou thy bloudy hands up, and boast thine,
And with a sharpe eye note, but with what scorne,
The English pay thy merit.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: This I'le try.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Dar'st thou alone meet me in Glasco-moore,
And there I'le tell thee more?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thou hast no treason towards me?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Here's my hand,
I am cleare as innocence, had I meant treason
Here could I worke it on thee, I have none.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: In Glasco-moore I'le meet thee, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: The time.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Some two houres hence.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: There I will untie
A knot, at which hangs death or Soveraigntie.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: We have swet hard to day.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Twas a brave hunting. Bolt offers to lay his Coat under the king.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Sit, some wine
Away in the field all fellows, whose is this?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: It was my Coat at Armes, but now tis yours at legges.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away, why givest thou me a cushion?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Because of the two, I take you to be the better man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A souldiers coat shall never be so base
To lye beneath my heele, th'art in this place
My fellow, and companion, a health to all in England.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Let it come.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Is not this he that kill'd Wallace?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: No sir, I am onely he that said so,
As you sit, so did I lye.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sirra, where's your master?

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: My master is shot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How shot, where?

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: I'th backe.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Oh he ranne away.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.p: No, my Lord, but his harnesse Cap was blowne off, and he running after it to catch it, was shot betweene necke and shoulders, and when he stood upright he had two heads.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Two heads how?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Yes truly, his own head and the arrow head, it was twenty to one that I had not beene shot before him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why prethee?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Because my Knights name being Wiseacres, and mine Bolt, and you know a fooles bolt is soon shot.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.p: He ha's pind the foole upon his masters shoulder very handsomly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Sirra, go seek your master, and bid him take order for burying of the dead.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: I shall Sir, and whilst he takes order for the burials of the dead, i'le take order for the stomacks of the living.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How fought to day our English?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Bravely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How the Scots?

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: The pangs of war are like to child-bed throwes
Bitter in suffering, but the storme being past,
The talk, as of scap't shipwrack sweet, doth taste,
The death of the Scotch Generall went to my heart,
He had in him of man asmuch as any,
And for ought I think, his bloud was poorly sold
By his own Countrymen, rather then sought by us.
Had not the Reare where Wallace did command,
Stood and given ayme, it had bin a day
Bloudy and dismall, and whose hard to say,
Sir, you shall give me leave to drink a health
To all the valiant Scots.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Clifford, I'le pledge thee, give me my bowle.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Sir, I remembred Wallace in my draught.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I did not, so this cup were Wallace Skull,
I'de drinke it full with bloud, for it would save
The lives of thousands.

sp.speaker: Clif
sp.l: I for your Kingdoms would not pledge it so.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I would, no matter how a traitor falls.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Percy, ten thousand Crowns should buy
That traitors head, if I could hav't for money.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I would give
Twice twenty thousand Crowns to have his head
On my swords point cut from him with this arme,
But how i'th field, nobly, hand to hand, not this straw
To a hangman that should bring it me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let that passe,
Wher's Bruce, our noble Earle of Carrick?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I saw him not to day,

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I did, and saw his sword
Like to a Reapers Sithe, mow down the Scots.
Here he comes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Brave Armory, a rampant Lion within a field all Gules,
Where hast been Bruce?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Following the execution which we held
Three English miles in length.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give him some wine, art not thirsty?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Yes for Scottish bloud, I never shall have
Enough on't, the Kings health.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Let come.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How greedily you Scot drinks his own bloud!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If he should taste your bitternesse, 'twere not well.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: What's that ye all laugh'd at?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Nothing but a jest.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir tell me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: An idle jest, more wine for Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: No more, I have drunk too much,
Wallace and I did parlee.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How in words?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: No Percy, I'me no prater, 'twas with swords,
Your laughing jest was not at me?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Sir, no.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bruce would fain quarrell,

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: I ha done sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Peace, what Trumpet's that?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: From the enemy sure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go learn.

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: I come from Wallace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So Sir, what of him?

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: Thus he speaks.
He bids me dare you to a fresh battaile, by to morrowes sunne,
Army to Army, troup to troup, he challenges,
Or to save bloud, fifty to fifty, shall the strife decide,
Or one to one.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A Herald to the traitor.
Go and thus speak, we bring whips of steele,
To scourge Rebellion, not to stand the braves
Of a base daring vassall, bid him ere that Sun
Which he calls up be risen, pay it and save
His Country and himselfe from ruine, charge him on his head,
To make his quick submission; if he slow the minutes,
Wee'le proclaime in thunder his and his Countries ruine,
Go be gon, Arme.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Arme, Arme.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A Land that's sick at heart must take sharp pils,
For dangerous physick best cures dangerous ils.

div.head: Actus V.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: As you are a souldier, as y'are noble
I charge you and conjure you to unclaspe
A book in which I am graveld.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Perhaps I cannot.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Yes, if you dare you can.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Dare? Clifford dares
Do any thing but wrong and what's not just.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Then tell me sir, what was that bitter scorn,
Which I like poyson tasted in my wine?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I care not if I doe, because I love vertue even in
My enemy, the bowle of wine kissing your lip.
Behold, quoth one how eagerly you Scot,
Drinks his own bloud.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: You Scot drinks his own bloud, which Scot?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Best wake some Oracle.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Who brake the jest upon me?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Pray pardon me. Exit Cli

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: The Oracle I'le wake is here, oh Wallace,
I ne're had eyes till now, they were clos'd up
By braving English, witchcraft drinks his own bloud,
England my stepdame take my bitter curse,
Thy own nails teare thy own bowels, oh my parent
Dear Scotland, I no more will be a goad,
Pricking thy sides, but if ere I draw a sword,
It shall be double-edg'd with bloud and fire,
To burn and drown this Kingdome and this King.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My Generall
Charg'd me in privacie to give you these.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Thanks noble Clifford, what did he bid thee say?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nothing but so. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: A pair of Spurs, Bruce nere was runaway,
Twelve silver pence, oh bitter scorn, with Judas,
I have betray'd my Master, my dear Country,
And here's the embleme of my treachery,
To hasten to some tree, and desperate die,
Twelve sterling silver pence, sterling, ha sterling,
'Tis a limbe of Scotland, spurs for flight,
Clifford, i'le thither, comment I wrong or right.

div.stage: Enter Grimsby, Mentith, Coming, English Herald, and Rouge-crosse.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Stay noble Grimsby, ere he further passe
One of us certifie our Generall,
Perhaps hee'l not admit him to his presence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: 'Tis like so, stay him here, that pains be mine.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Let Ruge-crosse bring his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Come agreed.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You bring from Longshanks some strange message now.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: At least he sends his Gauntlet.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Gauntlet, no the English
Fight not two dayes together, but like swaggerers,
A fray being made up with a wound or so,
The man whose throat before should have been cut,
Is a sworn brother, now we have mall'd your Nation,
Thei'le fawn on us like Spaniels, will they not?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: And that's thy errand, ist not?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: Commonly, when English see at cuffs they are too weak, they fall to fishing, and then bait the hook with mercie, and the Kings pardon, at which who bites ha's his swallowing spoiled for ever, there's no Scot but scorns to hang his hope on your Kings promises, be it nere so smoothly gilded.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: He gilds none sir.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: I warrant he would pawn half his Dominions to shake hands with Wallace, and be friends.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Had he but him in's Court, he would out-shine
His capring gallants, be would dote on him,
As Jupiter did on Ganymede, and make him
His chief Minion.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.p: Hee does already so really dote upon him, 'tis not yet the age of one houre since my Master sware to give ten thousand Crowns to Scot or English, that were so bold to bring him Wallace's head.

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: The English Herald.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Ten thousand Crowns.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Would make a faire shew in our purses Jack.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I could pick out five thousand heads,
That I durst boldly sell him at that rate.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Ten thousand Crowns.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I and Court wind-falls too,
Some English Earldome or so, here is none but friends,
Should you betray the conference, I care not,
I would deny it, and I would oresway
Your proofs tho neere so massie.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: It shall not need, beleeve me worthy Mentith.
What here you looke is safe.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: Shall we earne this English gold, ten thousand crownes?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My hand.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: They are ours, hee's dead.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: No more, he comes.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: I am to him no vassal, hee's a tyrant,
So tell him, ere his frowne shall bend my knee,
This shall be hang'd upon the gallow tree,
For my appearance tell him this, I'le dyne
On Christmas day next in his English Court,
And in his great Hall at Westminster, at's owne boord,
Wee'le drink Scotch healths in his standing cups of gold:
His blacke Iackes hand in hand about his Court
Shall march with our blew bonnets, we'le eate nothing
But what our swords shall carve, so tell his Souldiers,
Wee'le sit like Lords there whilst they rayle like slaves,
Go with Scotch threats, pay backe your English braves.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Youle make the English mad. Exit Herald.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A brave defiance.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Defiance,
Lets mad them more, they shall not sleep to night,
Good Grimsbie beat a drum, let bon-fires shine
Through all our army, as if our Tents were burnt,
And we dislodg'd, but recollect our troops
Into an ordered body, some thing wee'le do
To make our Chronicles swell with English rue.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: A Drum, call a Drum. Exit Grimsbie.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Oh sir John Mentith I have crackt the Ice,
To a designe, which if it will succeed,
England no more shall strike, nor Scotland bleed.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Com. Lets be partakers, deare sir.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: What will you say, if I winne Bruce from the English?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: The happiest day that ever shone on Scotland.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: And crowne him King?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: That's the up-shot must crowne all, I'm to meet him
Before one houre grow old in Glasco-moore.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: How meet him?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: As I am, both come alone, no words to any.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Our lips are seal'd.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Will you ride, or go on foot?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: No more, I'le ride.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Wee'le passe the wood on foot.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Jack Mentith, I do laugh to think what face,
Longshancks wil make, when he shall heare what guests
Will dine with him in's Court on Christmas day.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: What face? he'le kill the Herald sure.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Oh! some charme for me to be invisible there, and see him.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: For my part, of ten thousand crownes by this hand,
I do wish you there.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: For as many of mine, I sweare.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Time may come,
In his Exchequer we may share twice that summe.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Hence, hye you before, keep close in the wood,
Breake forth if you spie treason, if not, not.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Good. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Ha, if what thou seem'st thou art, step forward, speake,
I have fac'd more horrid terror.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Whare do'st gang?

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Thousese not lest and lang,
Twa wolves will suike thy bluide, by the third night,
I charge thy sawle meete mine, thy death is dight.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Thou art a lying spirit.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Bruce byn thy bane,
Gif on thou gang luke not turne backe againe,
Wallace beweere, me thinks it thee should irke,
Mare need hast thou to serve God in the Kirke.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Stay, if thou hast a voyce th'art bloud and bone,
As I am, let me feele thee, else I'le thinke thee
A sorcerous imaginarie sound:
Stand me, th'art some English damned witch,
That from a reverend Fryer has stoln his shape
To abuse me— stay— art gone? no Hagge I will not.
It spake sure, told me Bruce should Exit Ghost beckoning him to follow.
be my bane,— cannot— shall not,
heaven knows such things onely.
That eye hath shot me throw, wounds me to death,
I know that face too well, but 'tis so gastly,
I'le rather with my nayles here dig my grave,
Then once more behold thee. Exit Ghost.
Part from me vext spirit, my bloud turnes to water,
I beseech thee affright me not— it's gone.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Alace Scotland to wham salt thou compleyne,
Alace, fra mourning wha sall the refayne?
I thee beseek and for him dy'd on tree,
Come not nere Bruyce, yet Bruyce sall not hurt thee,
Alace, alace, no man can stand 'gainst fate.
The dampe dew fra the heaven does gyn to faw,
I to my rest mim gange ere the Cock crawe.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: It was my wife, what horror meete I here?
No Armour in the world can hold out feare.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: We stay for your direction.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Whom did you meete?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: No body.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Saw ye nothing?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Not any thing.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Twas my braines weaknesse then,
I have seene strange sights, that anon I'le tell;
If Grimsbie we meete never more, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Ha, I am strucke dumbe, oh mans slippery fate!
Mischiefes that follow us at our backs we shunne,
And are strucke downe with those we dreame not on.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I have beside with Wallace sherife of life,
Held private conference, who in Longshancks name,
Who sweares to me we shall have good preferment,
Beside the promist gold. Enter Wallace.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Peace, Wallace comes.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Is the Bruyce come?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: It is not yet his houre.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Who came along with you?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: My foot-boy onely, who is tying up my horse.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Him must I kill.
I'le looke if Bruce be in sight yet— Exit.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Y'are sad.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: My minde is shaken but the storme is o're,
What cry is that?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Be arm'd, Bruce with a force comes to betray thee,
From some villaines hand thy foot-boy is murdered.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Murdred? Bruce shall repent this deed.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: So shalt thou, away with him.

div.stage: Enter Souldiers, knocke him downe, hurry him away in a sound. Exeunt.
Enter Bruce muffled with a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Helpe to disguise me Souldier, in exchange
Take these for thine, and here's some gold to boot.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: If I be not hang'd, my Lord, in all my bravery,
I care not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Phew, I warrant thee,
Seale up thy lips and eyes, thou neither seest
Nor canst tell where I am.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Not I my Lord.
Oh my poore wrong'd countrey, pardon me heaven,
And with a feather pluck'd from mercies wing,
Brush off the purple spots, that else would grow,
Like freckles on my soule.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: My Lord, here comes company.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Here quicke mine own agen, and get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sirra Souldier, saw'st thou the Earle of Huntington?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Huntington?

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: The Lord Bruce, I meane.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Who cals for Bruce?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Muffled up, and alone, I'le to the King. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Do, sirra be gone.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Whither's Percy gone? he ask'd for Bruce.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: There's great enquirie for you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: The King has a fresh command for Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: For me? he may command his Subjects.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: True, and Huntington is one.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Is none.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: No Subject?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: None that dare oppose your King, Oh my impostum'd spleene,
Will flie into their faces, what command
Has England now?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Fresh powers are to be levied,
Which Bruce of Huntington must leade.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: 'Gainst whom?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Gainst proud Wallace, 'gainst the Scots.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: I will not, I'm not his Butcher,
Gainst the Scots I will not fight.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: How, will not?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: No, will not Clifford.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: My Lord, I dare not,
In this last battell I receiv'd some wounds
That yet bleed inward, I will no more banquet strangers
With my native bloud.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Bruce speaks not like a subject.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: English Edward commands not like a King,
Thrice honour'd Clifford, I'le trust you with my bosome.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: No, you shall not.
My virgin honour is so chast, it shall not
Keepe companie with a disquiet bosome,
Nor talke with discontents.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: It shall not, I will but,
Spare me, the ayre hath eares no more,
You sent to me, I will but tell bold Clifford
Not a word,
My thoughts owe as much honour as their Lord.
Within traytor, traytor. Enter Mentith.

div.stage: Enter King, North, Herefor, and followers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A mutinie, what noyse is't?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Mentith, a Knight of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Keepe him off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What com'st thou for?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Comyn my countryman and I have brought
A jewell to your Highnesse, which if 'twere right
As 'tis known counterfeit, 'twere worth a kingdome,
Wearied with warre, and pittying the deep wounds
Which fainting Scotland beares upon her breast,
And knowing that the onely sword which gashes
Her tender sides, is grip'd in Wallace hands,
I in my love to peace, and to the safetie
Of two great Nations, am the man that layed
Snares to entrap this monster, that devoures
So many thousand lives, the Rebell's tane.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I have brought him to your English Camp,
Force would not doo't, but policie, we struck the Stagge
To the ground, and thought him dead, but heaven put backe
The blow of purpose, hee's now come to life,
From an astonishment when we thought him dead,
To th'end the world may see the publique shame
Of an Arch-traytor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Mentith hath wonne fame,
And honour by this act, fetch in this devill. Exit Ment.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Thou wilt have Englands thanks, but Scotlands curse,
Thou never hast done better, never worse,
Damn'd Iudas to thy Country-man and friend.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Here with Bruce.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Bruce my Soveraigne?
My bloud is sold, this is not Glasco-moore,
Some villaine hath betray'd me.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Speak to your country-men, Comyn and Mentith.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Comyn and Mentith?
Something it was that made the modest night
Looke angry on the world, I this was it,
And this was it that cleft my fathers grave,
And rais'd him from his monumentall bed of earth
To give me gentle warning, this was it,
That made my starre, when all the rest look'd pale,
Blush like a fiery Meteor, can Heaven winke at this?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: It can, it doth, and at farre greater mischiefs.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Not of thy acting?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Yes of mine.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Not here.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Here or in Hell.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Why then goe act them there,
Boast of them there, in that black Kingdome tell
That by a true subject a base Rebell fell.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Your Scotch jeweller is slain,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: By Wallace.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Heare me speak King Edward.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Good my Liege heare him,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Clif. I have vow'd,
Neither to heare nor see him, drag him hence,
Mine eye shall nor be so compassionate
To view him, least I pitie him: hang, draw, and quarter him.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: First heare me speak,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Drag him hence, and let that heart, those limbes,
Which were the motives to rebellious warre
Be torn asunder, cast upon that ground,
Which he with unkinde steele so oft did wound,
Away with him.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Farewell, to all the World,
I ha met death too often to feare him now,
Only it grieves me that I have not freed
Scotland my native soile from tyranny,
Bruce, thou hast a Kingdome, lose it not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stop his throat.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: I go to one too,
And on my grave, when death hath there down laid me,
Be this my Epitaph, mine own betrayes me— Exit.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Let him have noble triall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He shall have the triall of an Arch-traitour,
Percy and Clifford take hence Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Me hence?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You hence sir, from this houre I sweare,
Never to see thee Earle of Huntingdon,
Harke Clifford, and Northumberland, awa

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: What is King Edwards meaning?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your head shal feel our meaning, see it dispatch'd.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: You may. Exeunt Bruce, North and Clifford.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My honor'd Lord, although untimely death,
Hath taken hence one engine of that work,
That brought that Rebell Wallace to his end.
Seeing our Countries peace, and Englands good,
Is by his death made perfect and compleat,
I doubt not but the promised reward
Of full ten thousand Crowns shall now remayn,
To the Survivor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Comin, I perceive
It was reward, not love that acted it,
But you shall have your due, of that anon. A flourish.
I told thee Bruce, that thou upon thy head,
Shouldst feele our meaning, and that all the world,
May know we value honour above conquest,
Having a power able to turn all Scotland
Into a Chaos, here twixt both our Armies,
Give us thy oath of fealty, and weare
Both Crown and title of thine Ancestors.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: England is full of honour, Bruce doth bend
To thy command. They crown him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give him his oath of fealty,
With him those Lords which are his Countrymen.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Stand back, a Serpent shall not with his breath
Infect our Kingly eares, die slave, for he
That would betray his friend shall nere serve me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What hath Bruce done?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: A sacrifice of honour and revenge, no traitors hand
Shall help to lift a Crown up to my head,
Thou didst betray, then die unpitied.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Brave Bruce, I'le love thee for this honor'd act,
Thou hast perform'd a noble piece of justice:
Now shall the Ghost of Wallace sleepe in peace,
And perfect love shall twixt these Lands increase.
He hath his full reward for his foule treason,
Drag hence the slave, and make him food for Crows.
The Lamp that gave Rebellion light, hath spent
The oile that fed it, all our spears are turn'd
To Palmes and Olive branches, all our stars
Are now made whole, peace is the balme of wars.
